[Use Autopilot for modern deployment - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/deploy-devices-windows-autopilot/2-use-autopilot-for-modern-deployment] & [Evaluate upgrades and migrations in modern transitioning - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/plan-transition-modern-endpoint-management/5-evaluate-upgrades-migrations-modern-transitioning] & [Windows deployment scenarios | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/deployment/windows-deployment-scenarios]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes the following devices:
Device1: Windows 10 Home
Device2: Windows 11 Professional
Device3: Windows 8.1 Enterprise
Device4: Android 9.0
You need to identify which devices support Intune configuration policies.
Which devices should you identify?
Question.Explanation: Device1, Device2, Device3 and Device4 can all be managed using Microsoft Intune. The minimum Windows version is Windows 8.1, the minimum Windows edition is Home and the minimum Android version is 8.0. [Operating systems and browsers supported by Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/fundamentals/supported-devices-browsers]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes 100 Windows 10 devices that are enrolled to Microsoft Intune.
You need to deploy Microsoft 365 Apps for Business to all devices. The solution must ensure that Microsoft Visio is included in the deployment.
What should you do first?

Option.Text: Assign a Visio license to your admin account.
Create a device configuration from the Microsoft 365 Apps admin center.
Create a device configuration profile from the Microsoft Intune admin center.
Create a new app configuration policy from the Microsoft Intune admin center.

Question.Explanation: A device configuration in the Microsoft 365 Apps Admin Center allows for the customization of the Microsoft 365 Apps installation, including Visio and/or Project. [Overview of the Microsoft 365 Apps admin center - Deploy Office | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/deployoffice/admincenter/overview]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
Users connect to Microsoft 365 services by using their personal iOS and Android devices. The devices are NOT managed by Intune.
You need to prevent Microsoft 365 files being saved locally to non-managed devices.
What should you use?
Question.Explanation: App Protection policies can secure apps on unmanaged devices, including preventing files from being saved locally. [Create and assign an app protection policy - Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/apps/quickstart-create-assign-app-policy]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes 100 users. Users access Microsoft 365 services by using Microsoft Edge on personal Android devices.
You need to deploy Microsoft Edge bookmarks to the Android devices.
What should you configure?
Question.Explanation: An App Configuration policy allows for app settings to be configured regardless of the device's enrollment state or how the app is delivered to the device. [App configuration policies for Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-overview]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes iOS and Android devices that are managed by using Microsoft Intune.
You plan to implement a data protection framework for financial data.
You need to create app protection policies for the framework to protect company data in the event that a device is rooted or jailbroken.
What two actions should the policy perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
Question.Explanation: The finance department has access to financial data that poses a uniquely high risk. Any change into devices that become jailbroken or rooted should immediately result in a wipe to ensure no data can be retrieved. All organization data should be encrypted on the device by default. [Data protection framework using app protection policies - Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-framework]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription. The subscription contains a user named User1 and a Microsoft Entra joined device named Device1 that runs Windows 11 Pro.
You need to implement subscription activation for Device1.
What should you do?

Option.Text: Configure Windows Autopilot and create a deployment profile.
Enroll Device1 to Microsoft Intune and assign a compliance policy.
Enroll Device1 to Microsoft Intune and assign a device configuration profile.

Question.Explanation: Subscription activation is performed by assigning a user a Windows 10/11 Enterprise license. When a user signs in to a Windows Pro device, the device is automatically and transparently activated and upgraded to the Enterprise edition. [MD-102 2-Implement dynamic deployment methods - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/implement-dynamic-deployment/] & [Windows subscription activation - Windows Deployment | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/deployment/windows-10-subscription-activation]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E3 subscription that includes 500 devices and uses Microsoft Intune. The devices run Windows 10 22H2 and are configured with Windows Recovery Environment.
You need to deploy Windows Autopilot. The solution must minimize the time taken to revert devices to a business-ready state.
What should you do first?

Option.Text: Manually register the devices with Windows Autopilot.

Question.Explanation: The first step is to create a deployment profile that converts all targeted devices to Autopilot devices. [Windows Autopilot Reset | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/autopilot/windows-autopilot-reset] & [Configure Autopilot profiles | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/autopilot/profiles]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.
You create a Windows Autopilot deployment profile named Profile1.
You need to ensure that devices are automatically joined to Microsoft Entra ID as part of the deployment. The solution must ensure that users can only sign into the device using their Microsoft 365 account.
What setting should you configure?
Question.Explanation: Hiding the change account options will prevent new devices from displaying on the company sign-in and domain error pages. [Configure Autopilot profiles | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/autopilot/profiles]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to ensure that any Intune managed Windows 10 Device that has been inactive for 180 days is automatically wiped and that the enrollment is deleted from Microsoft Intune.
What should you configure?
Question.Explanation: Device Cleanup rules can be configured to automatically delete and wipe any device that has been inactive for a configured period of time between 30 and 270 days. Compliance policies measure the compliance of a device against configured criteria and can mark a device as non-compliant and Configuration profiles allow settings to be deployed to Intune enrolled devices, but neither will automatically delete and wipe a device. Security Baselines are Configuration profiles apply best practice security configurations to devices. [Retire or wipe devices using Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/remote-actions/devices-wipe]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription and 50 iOS devices.
You plan to implement Defender for Endpoint for all corporate iOS devices.
You need to onboard the iOS devices to Defender for Endpoint.
What tool should you use?
Question.Explanation: Only Intune allows you to deploy the Microsoft Defender Endpoint app for iOS devices. Group policies, local scripts, and JAMF Pro are not allowed on an iOS device. [Onboard devices and configure Microsoft Defender for Endpoint capabilities | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/onboard-configure?view=o365-worldwide]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes 500 Android tablets that are managed by using Microsoft Intune.
You need to ensure that updates are automatically deployed to the tablets.
What should you configure?
Question.Explanation: Only the Device restrictions policy for organization allows you to set these settings which can be configured using a device restriction configuration profile. [Corporate-owned Android Enterprise device restriction settings in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/configuration/device-restrictions-android-for-work]

Question.Text:
Your company has a diverse range of devices, including both company-owned and BYOD (Bring Your Own Device), that need to access Microsoft 365 services. The IT department wants to ensure that sensitive company data is protected on all devices, regardless of whether they are managed by Intune.
How should you create app protection policies to apply different levels of data loss prevention (DLP) controls based on whether the device is managed by Intune or not?
Each correct answer presents part of the solution. What two actions should you perform?

Option.Text: Configure device compliance policies instead of app protection policies.
Create a separate app protection policy for Intune managed devices with relaxed DLP controls.
Create a single app protection policy and apply it to all devices.
Create one app protection policy for unmanaged devices with strict DLP controls.
Use conditional access policies to enforce DLP controls.

Question.Explanation: Creating a separate app protection policy for Intune-managed devices with relaxed DLP controls (B) is correct because managed devices are already secured, allowing for more flexible policies. Creating one app protection policy for unmanaged devices with strict DLP controls (D) is correct because unmanaged devices pose a higher risk, so stricter policies help protect sensitive data. Configuring device compliance policies (A) is incorrect because compliance policies focus on device health, not app-specific data protection. Using a single policy for all devices (C) is incorrect because it doesn’t differentiate between managed and unmanaged devices. Conditional access (E) is incorrect because it controls access but doesn’t apply specific DLP controls within apps. [Deploy applications with Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/deploy-applications/2-deploy-applications-intune] & [Implement mobile application management policies in Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/execute-mobile-application-management/5-implement-mobile-application-management-policies-intune] & [Policies for Office apps - Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/apps/app-office-policies]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes 100 Android devices that are enrolled to Microsoft Intune.
You plan to deploy an Android app to all managed Android devices by using Microsoft Intune.
You create a new app deployment and enter the name and details of the app.
What should you do next?

Option.Text: Enter the AppStore URL for the app.
Enter the publishers download URL for the app.
Upload the APK for the app to Azure storage.
Upload the APK for the app to the Microsoft Intune admin center.

Question.Explanation: The AppStore URL is required during the app deployment and allows the app to be located and installed on devices. Uploading the APK for the app is not required to deploy an Android application and the publisher URL is not required, this must be a link to the public Play Store URL. [Add Android store apps to Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/apps/store-apps-android]

Question.Text:
Your company is implementing a new email application for its employees. The IT department wants to ensure that the application is configured to block external images and restrict certain URLs for security reasons. Employees use a mix of iOS and Android devices, both managed and unmanaged.
What two actions should you perform to apply these configurations to the email application across all devices?

Option.Text: Create a separate app protection policy for each device type.
Create an app configuration policy for managed apps and include the required settings.
Create an app configuration policy for managed devices and include the required settings.
Instruct employees to manually configure the email application settings.

Question.Explanation: Creating an app configuration policy for managed apps (B) is correct because it allows you to enforce settings, such as blocking external images and restricting certain URLs, across all managed devices consistently. Creating an app configuration policy for managed devices (C) is also correct as it ensures that the required security configurations are applied to those devices, maintaining compliance. Creating separate app protection policies for each device type (A) is incorrect because it does not specifically address the requirements for blocking images and URLs. Instructing employees to manually configure the email application settings (D) is inefficient and could lead to inconsistent application of security policies. [Deploy applications with Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/deploy-applications/2-deploy-applications-intune] & [Implement mobile application management policies in Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/execute-mobile-application-management/5-implement-mobile-application-management-policies-intune] & [App configuration policies for Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-overview]

Question.Text:
Your company is moving to a cloud-first infrastructure and needs to ensure that all devices accessing its resources comply with security policies. These devices include a mix of company-owned and personal devices across Windows, iOS, and Android platforms.
You need to implement a solution that allows both types of devices to access organizational resources while ensuring they meet security compliance.
Each correct answer presents part of the solution. Which three actions should you perform?

Option.Text: Apply Conditional Access policies to enforce compliance.
Register user-owned devices to Microsoft Entra ID.
Require all devices to use a Microsoft account for sign-in.
Use Group Policy Objects (GPOs) to manage device compliance.

Question.Explanation: Registering user-owned devices to Microsoft Entra ID allows the organization to recognize and manage these devices. Enrolling devices in Microsoft Intune ensures that they can be managed and meet security compliance requirements. Applying Conditional Access policies enforces compliance before allowing access to organizational resources. Requiring all devices to use a Microsoft account for sign-in is unnecessary, and using Group Policy Objects (GPOs) is not relevant for managing compliance in a cloud-first infrastructure. [Use Microsoft Entra join with automatic MDM enrollment - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/implement-dynamic-deployment/5-use-azure-ad-join-automatic-mobile-device-management-enrollment] & [Examine Microsoft Entra join prerequisites limitations and benefits - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/administer-device-authentication/3-examine-azure-active-directory-join-prerequisites-limitations-benefits] & [What are Microsoft Entra registered devices? - Microsoft Entra ID | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/entra/identity/devices/concept-device-registration]

Question.Text:
Your company is preparing to deploy a large number of Android devices for field agents. These devices must be centrally managed and restricted to access only specific work-related applications. The devices will not be used for personal purposes.
What steps should you take to configure the enrollment settings for these Android devices to ensure they are fully managed and restricted to work-related use?

Option.Text: Configure an Android device administrator enrollment profile.
Configure an Android Enterprise dedicated device enrollment profile.
Configure an Android Enterprise fully managed enrollment profile.
Configure an Android Enterprise work profile enrollment profile.

Question.Explanation: Configuring an Android Enterprise fully managed enrollment profile (C) ensures that the devices are fully managed by Intune and restricted to work-related use. An Android Enterprise work profile (D) is more appropriate for BYOD scenarios, while an Android Enterprise dedicated device profile (B) is intended for single-use devices, such as kiosks. An Android device administrator profile (A) does not provide the same level of management and control, making it unsuitable for this scenario. [Enroll devices using Microsoft Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/enroll-devices-use-intune/] & [Step 5 – Enroll devices in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/fundamentals/deployment-guide-enroll?tabs=work-profile%2Ccorporate-owned-apple%2Cautomatic-enrollment]

Question.Text:
Your company wants to implement Conditional Access policies to protect organizational data. They need to ensure that only devices compliant with their Intune policies can access Microsoft 365 services.
How should you configure the devices to implement these Conditional Access policies?
Each correct answer is part of the solution. What three actions should you take?

Option.Text: Assign the Conditional Access policy to the user group accessing Microsoft 365 services.
Configure the policy to allow access from unmanaged devices.
Create a Conditional Access policy in Microsoft Entra ID.
Enable location-based access control in the Conditional Access policy.
Set the policy to require device compliance from Intune.

Question.Explanation: Assigning the Conditional Access policy to the user group accessing Microsoft 365 services (A) ensures that the policy applies specifically to the users who need access, enforcing compliance for that group. Creating a Conditional Access policy in Microsoft Entra ID (C) is necessary to define and enforce access rules based on device compliance. Setting the policy to require device compliance from Intune (E) ensures that only compliant devices are allowed access to Microsoft 365 services. Configuring the policy to allow access from unmanaged devices (B) contradicts the goal of ensuring only compliant devices can access services, and enabling location-based access control (D) manages access based on location but does not enforce compliance with Intune policies. [MD-102 3-Implement device compliance - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/implement-device-compliance/] & [Windows compliance settings in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/protect/compliance-policy-create-windows]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to enforce Intune compliance for the following device types:
iPad
iPhone
Windows 11
Windows 10
Android
What is the minimum number of Compliance policies required?
Question.Explanation: Three is correct. At a minimum, Android Enterprise, iOS/iPadOS, and Windows 10 and later Compliance policies are required. [Device compliance policies in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/protect/device-compliance-get-started]

Question.Text:
Your company has implemented Microsoft Intune to manage devices, but some devices are accessing corporate resources without being compliant with the company's security policies.
How should you configure the devices to ensure that only compliant devices can access corporate resources?
Each correct answer is part of the solution. What three actions should you take?

Option.Text: Configure Conditional Access policies to require device compliance.
Create and assign device compliance policies to user groups.
Deploy a device configuration policy to enforce encryption.
Enable Enhanced jailbreak detection for iOS devices.
Set the 'Compliance status validity period' to 60 days.
Set the 'Mark devices with no compliance policy assigned as' setting to 'Not compliant'.

Question.Explanation: Configuring Conditional Access policies to require device compliance (A) ensures that only devices meeting your organization's compliance policies can access corporate resources. Creating and assigning device compliance policies to user groups (B) defines the compliance requirements, such as security settings, that devices must adhere to. Setting the 'Mark devices with no compliance policy assigned as' setting to 'Not compliant' (F) ensures that any devices without a compliance policy are treated as non-compliant and restricted from accessing resources. Deploying a device configuration policy to enforce encryption (C) focuses on configuring specific device settings but does not directly manage access. Enabling Enhanced jailbreak detection (D) is limited to iOS devices, and setting the 'Compliance status validity period' (E) affects how long devices remain compliant but does not actively enforce compliance. [MD-102 3-Implement device compliance - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/implement-device-compliance/] & [Device compliance policies in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/protect/device-compliance-get-started]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes 500 Windows 11 devices that are managed by using Microsoft Intune.
Your company uses Intune to manage devices and has configured compliance policies and conditional access policies. Several users complain they cannot access company resources.
You must identify potential problems for all users. The solution must require minimal administrative effort.
Which two services can you use to get an overview of potential problems? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.

Option.Text: View the details of the created policy.

Question.Explanation: The details of a policy provide a diagram overview and the device compliance report provides details for all devices. [Monitor results of your device compliance policies in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/protect/compliance-policy-monitor]

Question.Text:
Your company has a diverse range of devices, including both company-owned and BYOD (Bring Your Own Device), that need to access Microsoft 365 services. The IT department wants to ensure that sensitive company data is protected on all devices, regardless of whether they are managed by Intune.
How should you create app protection policies to apply different levels of data loss prevention (DLP) controls based on whether the device is managed by Intune or not?
Each correct answer presents part of the solution. What two actions should you perform?

Option.Text: Configure device compliance policies instead of app protection policies.
Create a separate app protection policy for Intune managed devices with relaxed DLP controls.
Create a single app protection policy and apply it to all devices.
Create one app protection policy for unmanaged devices with strict DLP controls.
Use conditional access policies to enforce DLP controls.

Question.Explanation: Creating a separate app protection policy for Intune-managed devices with relaxed DLP controls (B) is correct because managed devices are already secured, allowing for more flexible policies. Creating one app protection policy for unmanaged devices with strict DLP controls (D) is correct because unmanaged devices pose a higher risk, so stricter policies help protect sensitive data. Configuring device compliance policies (A) is incorrect because compliance policies focus on device health, not app-specific data protection. Using a single policy for all devices (C) is incorrect because it doesn’t differentiate between managed and unmanaged devices. Conditional access (E) is incorrect because it controls access but doesn’t apply specific DLP controls within apps. [Deploy applications with Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/deploy-applications/2-deploy-applications-intune] & [Implement mobile application management policies in Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/execute-mobile-application-management/5-implement-mobile-application-management-policies-intune] & [Policies for Office apps - Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/apps/app-office-policies]

Question.Text:
Your company is implementing a BYOD policy for employees using Android devices. They need to ensure that work and personal data remain separate on these devices.
You need to configure the appropriate enrollment profile for these Android devices.
Which enrollment profile should you configure?
Question.Explanation: The Android Enterprise work profile (C) is designed to keep work and personal data separate on BYOD devices. The fully managed (B) and dedicated (A) profiles are intended for corporate-owned devices, and the Device Enrollment Manager (DEM) (D) is used for enrolling large numbers of devices by an administrator, making it unsuitable for a BYOD scenario. [Enroll devices using Microsoft Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/enroll-devices-use-intune/] & [Set up automatic enrollment in Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/enrollment/quickstart-setup-auto-enrollment]

Question.Text:
You manage a network that contains the following devices:
Device1, Windows 11 Enterprise
Device2, Windows 11 Pro
Device3, Windows 11 for Education
Device4, Windows 11 Home
Which devices can be added to an Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) domain?
Question.Explanation:
Device1, Device2, and Device3 is correct. Windows 11 Enterprise, Windows 11 Pro and Windows 11 for Education are all supported for Active Directory domain Join. Windows 11 Home is not.
Device1 only is incorrect. Windows 11 Enterprise, Windows 11 Pro and Windows 11 for Education are all supported for Active Directory domain Join. Windows 11 Home is not.
Device1 and Device2 is incorrect. Windows 11 Enterprise, Windows 11 Pro and Windows 11 for Education are all supported for Active Directory domain Join. Windows 11 Home is not.
Device1, Device2, Device3, and Device4 is incorrect. Windows 11 Enterprise, Windows 11 Pro and Windows 11 for Education are all supported for Active Directory domain Join. Windows 11 Home is not. [Examine Windows client editions and requirements - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/examine-windows-client-editions-requirements/]

Question.Text:
You have an on-premises network and a hybrid Microsoft 365 that uses Microsoft Entra Connect.
You need to identify the devices that will be visible by using the Microsoft Entra admin center.
What should you identify?

Option.Text: Microsoft Entra hybrid joined devices and Active Directory Domain joined devices only
Microsoft Entra joined devices, Microsoft Entra hybrid joined devices, and Microsoft Entra registered Devices only
Active Directory Domain joined devices, Microsoft Entra joined devices, Microsoft Entra hybrid joined devices, and Microsoft Entra registered devices

Question.Explanation:
Active Directory joined devices are not present in the Microsoft Entra admin center.
Microsoft Entra joined devices, Microsoft Entra Hybrid joined devices, and Microsoft Entra registered devices are present and viewable from the Microsoft Entra admin center. [What is device identity in Microsoft Entra ID? - Microsoft Entra ID | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/entra/identity/devices/overview]

Question.Text:
Your company needs to enroll a large number of iOS devices for their sales team. These devices are company-owned and need to be managed with minimal user interaction. The company also wants the devices to be enrolled in supervised mode and shipped directly to users.
You need to configure the enrollment settings for these iOS devices.
Which two actions should you perform?

Option.Text: Create an enrollment profile in the Intune admin center.
Instruct users to manually install the Company Portal app from the App Store.
Use Apple Business Manager to configure Automated Device Enrollment (ADE).
Use Apple Configurator to enroll the devices.

Question.Explanation: Using Apple Business Manager to configure Automated Device Enrollment (ADE) (C) allows for bulk enrollment of company-owned devices in supervised mode with minimal user interaction. Creating an enrollment profile in the Intune admin center (A) ensures that the devices receive the necessary configurations automatically. Manually installing the Company Portal app (B) and using Apple Configurator (D) are less efficient and involve more manual steps, making them unsuitable for this large-scale deployment scenario. [Enroll devices using Microsoft Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/enroll-devices-use-intune/] & [iOS/iPadOS device enrollment guide for Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/fundamentals/deployment-guide-enrollment-ios-ipados]

Question.Text:
Your company has implemented Microsoft Intune to manage devices, but some devices are accessing corporate resources without being compliant with the company's security policies.
How should you configure the devices to ensure that only compliant devices can access corporate resources?
Each correct answer is part of the solution. What three actions should you take?

Option.Text: Configure Conditional Access policies to require device compliance.
Create and assign device compliance policies to user groups.
Deploy a device configuration policy to enforce encryption.
Enable Enhanced jailbreak detection for iOS devices.
Set the 'Compliance status validity period' to 60 days.
Set the 'Mark devices with no compliance policy assigned as' setting to 'Not compliant'.

Question.Explanation: Configuring Conditional Access policies to require device compliance (A) ensures that only devices meeting your organization's compliance policies can access corporate resources. Creating and assigning device compliance policies to user groups (B) defines the compliance requirements, such as security settings, that devices must adhere to. Setting the 'Mark devices with no compliance policy assigned as' setting to 'Not compliant' (F) ensures that any devices without a compliance policy are treated as non-compliant and restricted from accessing resources. Deploying a device configuration policy to enforce encryption (C) focuses on configuring specific device settings but does not directly manage access. Enabling Enhanced jailbreak detection (D) is limited to iOS devices, and setting the 'Compliance status validity period' (E) affects how long devices remain compliant but does not actively enforce compliance. [MD-102 3-Implement device compliance - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/implement-device-compliance/] & [Device compliance policies in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/protect/device-compliance-get-started]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes 500 Windows 11 devices that are managed by using Microsoft Intune.
You create a new Compliance policy notification to alert device owners when their devices become non-compliant.
How will users be notified if their device becomes non-compliant?
Question.Explanation: Users will be notified using email notifications as they are the only option supported by Microsoft Intune. SMS, Windows notifications, and phone toast notifications are not supported by Microsoft Intune. [Send notifications to noncompliant devices - Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/protect/quickstart-send-notification]

Question.Text:
Your company is planning to deploy Windows 11 to its fleet of 500 devices. They want to ensure that the deployment process is streamlined and that all devices are configured uniformly. The fleet includes both new and existing devices, and the company aims to minimize manual intervention during the deployment process.
How should you approach the deployment to ensure uniform configuration and minimal manual effort?

Option.Text: Deploy Windows upgrade with Microsoft Configuration Manager.
Implement Windows client deployment by using Windows Autopilot.
Perform an in-place upgrade on each device manually.
Use provisioning packages for all devices.

Question.Explanation: Implementing Windows client deployment by using Windows Autopilot (B) is correct because Autopilot automates the deployment process, minimizing manual intervention and ensuring uniform configuration across both new and existing devices. It is ideal for large-scale deployments where consistency and automation are key. Deploying Windows upgrades with Microsoft Configuration Manager (A) is incorrect because although it’s powerful for managing deployments, the question focuses on Autopilot. Performing an in-place upgrade manually (C) is inefficient and labor-intensive, making it unsuitable for a large fleet of 500 devices. Using provisioning packages for all devices (D) is incorrect because provisioning packages are typically used for smaller-scale, specific configurations and are not ideal for full OS deployments. [Additional Microsoft 365 Apps Deployment Tools - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/administer-endpoint-applications/5-additional-microsoft-365-apps-deployment-tools] & [Explore Windows 365 - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/manage-windows-365/2-explore-windows-365] & [Deploy Windows with Microsoft 365 | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/deployment/deploy-m365]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.
You have the following devices enrolled in Intune:
Device1: Windows 11
Device2: macOS
Device3: iPadOS
You plan to use a template to create an Endpoint Protection device configuration profile in Intune.
For which devices can you create an Endpoint Protection device configuration profile template?
Question.Explanation: The Endpoint Protection device configuration template is available only for Windows 10 and later and macOS platforms. This profile is unavailable for iPadOS platform. [Execute device profiles - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/execute-device-profiles/] & [Create device profiles in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/configuration/device-profile-create]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.
Users enroll Windows 11 devices in Intune.
You need to configure an update schedule during which Windows updates are installed on the enrolled devices.
What should you configure in Intune?

Option.Text: feature updates for Windows 10 and later
quality updates for Windows 10 and later
update ring for Windows 10 and later

Question.Explanation: Update rings specify how and when Windows as a Service updates Windows 10/11 devices with feature and quality updates. An update ring includes the User experience settings, in which you can configure the automatic update features (including auto install and restart at maintenance time), active hours start, and active hours end. [Configure Update rings for Windows 10 and later policy in Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/protect/windows-10-update-rings]

Question.Text:
Your company has a diverse range of devices, including both company-owned and BYOD (Bring Your Own Device), that need to access Microsoft 365 services. The IT department wants to ensure that sensitive company data is protected on all devices, regardless of whether they are managed by Intune.
How should you create app protection policies to apply different levels of data loss prevention (DLP) controls based on whether the device is managed by Intune or not?
Each correct answer presents part of the solution. What two actions should you perform?

Option.Text: Configure device compliance policies instead of app protection policies.
Create a separate app protection policy for Intune managed devices with relaxed DLP controls.
Create a single app protection policy and apply it to all devices.
Create one app protection policy for unmanaged devices with strict DLP controls.
Use conditional access policies to enforce DLP controls.

Question.Explanation: Creating a separate app protection policy for Intune-managed devices with relaxed DLP controls (B) is correct because managed devices are already secured, allowing for more flexible policies. Creating one app protection policy for unmanaged devices with strict DLP controls (D) is correct because unmanaged devices pose a higher risk, so stricter policies help protect sensitive data. Configuring device compliance policies (A) is incorrect because compliance policies focus on device health, not app-specific data protection. Using a single policy for all devices (C) is incorrect because it doesn’t differentiate between managed and unmanaged devices. Conditional access (E) is incorrect because it controls access but doesn’t apply specific DLP controls within apps. [Deploy applications with Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/deploy-applications/2-deploy-applications-intune] & [Implement mobile application management policies in Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/execute-mobile-application-management/5-implement-mobile-application-management-policies-intune] & [Policies for Office apps - Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/apps/app-office-policies]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes a group named Group1 that contains 500 Android devices.
You provision a new App Protection policy in Microsoft Intune with the following settings:
Target to apps on all device types: Yes
Target Policy to: All Microsoft Apps
Save copies of org data: Block
Allow user to save copies to selected services: OneDrive for Business
Assignments: Group1
Users report that they can save data to their devices.
You need to ensure that users are prevented from saving data to their local devices.
Which setting should you modify?

Option.Text: Allow user to save copies to selected services

Question.Explanation: The Assignments setting needs to be modified to include either All devices or All users. Assigning the policy to a security group containing devices will not capture new devices or devices that are not registered in Microsoft Entra ID. [Create and deploy app protection policies - Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policies]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You purchase 100 Windows devices that will be deployed to new users.
You need to ensure that you can deploy the devices by manually registering the devices using Windows Autopilot.
What should you do first?

Option.Text: Upload the device name of each device to Microsoft Intune.
Upload the hardware ID of each device to Microsoft Intune.
Upload the IP address of each device to Microsoft Intune.
Upload the MAC address of each device to Microsoft Intune.

Question.Explanation: Windows Autopilot requires the hardware ID of each machine to be uploaded before the machine can be used with Autopilot. The MAC address, device name, and IP address is not needed for Windows Autopilot. [Manually register devices with Windows Autopilot | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/autopilot/add-devices]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.
You create a Windows Autopilot deployment profile named Profile1.
You need to manually register a device to test Profile1.
What information can you use to register the device?
Question.Explanation: To register a new device in Microsoft Intune you must capture the Hardware Hash The MAC address, as a unique identifier, is not required to capture the hardware hash if you can sign into the device and can use PowerShell. The PKID (Windows product ID) and tuple are not valid options to register a new device to Microsoft Intune or a profile. [Manually register devices with Windows Autopilot | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/autopilot/add-devices] & [Configure Autopilot profiles | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/autopilot/profiles]

Question.Text:
You want to ensure that all new Windows 11 devices are joined to Microsoft Entra ID during the out-of-box experience (OOBE). The IT department has configured the device registration service and ensured that all necessary prerequisites are met.
You need to join the new Windows 11 devices to Microsoft Entra ID during the OOBE.
Each correct answer presents part of the solution. Which three actions should you perform?

Option.Text: Provide the credentials that your organization provided.
Select 'Set up for work or school' when prompted.
Select 'This device belongs to my family' when prompted.
Skip the network connection step during setup.
Turn on the new device and start the setup process.

Question.Explanation: Turning on the device and starting the setup process (A) is the first step. Selecting 'Set up for work or school' (B) ensures the device is prepared for Microsoft Entra ID join. Providing the organization's credentials (C) completes the authentication process. Selecting 'This device belongs to my family' (D) is incorrect as it does not align with the goal. Skipping the network connection step (E) is incorrect because the device must be connected to the Internet to complete the Microsoft Entra join. [Manage device authentication - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/administer-device-authentication/] & [Join a new Windows 11 device with Microsoft Entra ID during the out of box experience - Microsoft Entra ID | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/entra/identity/devices/device-join-out-of-box]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes a user named User1.
You need to ensure that User1 can enroll 150 Windows devices to Microsoft Intune. The solution must follow the principle of least privilege.
Which role should you assign to User1?
Question.Explanation: A Device Enrollment Manager is a non-administrative account that can enroll up to 1000 devices. Intune Service Administrators and Global Administrators would be granted more permissions than required. No role assignment is also incorrect. Standard users can enroll a maximum of 15 devices.

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes 500 Windows 11 devices that are managed by using Microsoft Intune.
You need to deploy a Conditional Access policy that will ensure that users can only access the subscription from Windows devices that have BitLocker enabled.
What should you do first?
Question.Explanation: In order to ensure that users can only access your subscription from Windows devices with BitLocker enabled, you need to mark devices as compliant or not compliant by using a device Compliance policy as a first step. [Create device compliance policies in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/protect/create-compliance-policy]

Question.Text:
Your company is planning to deploy a new set of Windows devices to the sales team. These devices need to be pre-configured with specific security settings and applications before being distributed to users.
How should you automate the configuration process to ensure consistency and reduce manual effort?
Each correct answer is part of the solution. What two actions should you take?

Option.Text: Create a device configuration profile in Intune and assign it to the sales team devices.
Enable BitLocker encryption on each device manually.
Manually install the required applications on each device.
Set up a Local Administrative Password Solution (LAPS) for the devices.
Use Windows Autopilot to pre-configure the devices.

Question.Explanation: Creating a device configuration profile in Intune and assigning it to the sales team devices (A) ensures that all devices receive consistent security settings, automating part of the configuration process. Using Windows Autopilot to pre-configure the devices (E) automates the deployment, including the installation of required applications and settings, ensuring consistency while reducing manual effort. Enabling BitLocker encryption manually (B) and manually installing applications (C) are labor-intensive processes that do not align with the goal of automation. Setting up a Local Administrative Password Solution (LAPS) (D) manages admin passwords but does not assist in pre-configuring devices with security settings and applications. [Manage mobile devices with Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/enroll-devices-use-intune/2-manage-mobile-devices-intune] & [Deploy applications with Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/deploy-applications/2-deploy-applications-intune] & [Manage and secure devices in Intune - Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/fundamentals/manage-devices]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that contains devices that run Windows 11.
All the devices are enrolled in Microsoft Intune.
You need to ensure that the devices use Delivery Optimization when installing Windows updates.
What should you configure in Intune?

Option.Text: feature updates for Windows 10 and later
quality updates for Windows 10 and later
update ring for Windows 10 and later

Question.Explanation: Delivery Optimization reduces bandwidth consumption when devices download applications and updates. You can configure Delivery Optimization by using a device configuration profile and selecting the Delivery Optimization template. [Delivery Optimization settings for Windows devices in Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/configuration/delivery-optimization-windows]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes 100 Windows devices that are enrolled in Microsoft Intune.
You notice an update has caused an issue with an existing application.
You need to pause the update ring.
What is the maximum amount of time the update ring can be paused?
Question.Explanation: 35 days is correct. The maximum amount of time an update ring can be paused is 35 days. [Configure Update rings for Windows 10 and later policy in Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/protect/windows-10-update-rings]

Question.Text:
Your company is transitioning to a cloud-first infrastructure and wants to ensure that all devices accessing their resources are compliant with their security policies. They have a mix of organization-owned and user-owned devices, including Windows, iOS, and Android devices.
You need to configure the devices to join Microsoft Entra ID and ensure they comply with the organization's security policies.
Each correct answer presents part of the solution. Which two actions should you perform?

Option.Text: Configure the devices to use local accounts only.
Enroll the devices in Microsoft Intune.
Register the devices to Microsoft Entra ID.

Question.Explanation: Enroll the devices in Microsoft Intune to manage and enforce compliance policies. Register the devices to Microsoft Entra ID to enable access to organizational resources. Configuring devices to use local accounts only would not provide the necessary access to resources. Disabling Conditional Access policies would reduce security. Using a third-party MDM solution is not necessary when Microsoft Intune can be used. [Use Microsoft Entra join with automatic MDM enrollment - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/implement-dynamic-deployment/5-use-azure-ad-join-automatic-mobile-device-management-enrollment] & [Examine Microsoft Entra join prerequisites limitations and benefits - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/administer-device-authentication/3-examine-azure-active-directory-join-prerequisites-limitations-benefits] & [What are Microsoft Entra registered devices? - Microsoft Entra ID | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/entra/identity/devices/concept-device-registration]

Question.Text:
Your company plans to deploy Android devices for field workers. These devices need to be fully managed and restricted to work-related applications only.
You need to configure the enrollment profiles for these Android devices.
Each correct answer contributes to the solution. Which two actions should you take?

Option.Text: Configure a compliance policy to restrict access to personal applications.
Connect your Intune tenant account to your Managed Google Play account.
Create a Device Enrollment Manager (DEM) account for the field workers.
Enable automatic enrollment for Android devices in Microsoft Intune.
Set up an Android Enterprise fully managed enrollment profile in Microsoft Intune.

Question.Explanation: Setting up an Android Enterprise fully managed enrollment profile (E) ensures that the devices are fully managed and restricted to work-related applications. Connecting the Intune tenant account to the Managed Google Play account (B) is necessary for managing Android Enterprise devices. Creating a DEM account (C) is not relevant for this scenario, as it is not suitable for fully managed corporate devices. Enabling automatic enrollment (D) is not applicable for Android devices in this context. Configuring a compliance policy (A) is a separate task and does not directly relate to the initial enrollment configuration. [Enroll devices using Microsoft Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/enroll-devices-use-intune/] & [Tutorial - Use Apple Business Manager to enroll iOS/iPadOS devices in Intune - Microsoft Intune | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/enrollment/tutorial-use-device-enrollment-program-enroll-ios]

Question.Text:
Your company is planning to deploy Windows Hello for Business in a hybrid environment using both on-premises Active Directory and Microsoft Entra ID. They want to ensure a seamless deployment without conflicts between Group Policy and Intune settings.
How should you configure the devices to implement Windows Hello for Business in this hybrid environment?

Option.Text: Configure Windows Hello for Business settings in both Intune and Group Policy without any coordination.
Disable Windows Hello for Business in Intune and use only on-premises AD DS settings.
Use Intune to manage Windows Hello for Business settings and ensure no overlapping settings with Group Policy.
Use only Group Policy to manage Windows Hello for Business settings.

Question.Explanation: Using Intune to manage Windows Hello for Business settings and ensuring no overlapping settings with Group Policy (C) is the correct solution because it allows for centralized management in a hybrid environment and avoids conflicts between Group Policy and Intune settings. Configuring settings in both Intune and Group Policy without coordination (A) could lead to conflicts, making the deployment inconsistent. Disabling Windows Hello for Business in Intune and using only on-premises AD DS settings (B) limits cloud management capabilities, reducing the flexibility and effectiveness of the deployment. Using only Group Policy (D) restricts the ability to manage devices through Intune, which is essential in a hybrid environment where cloud-based management is needed. [MD-102 1-Protect identities in Microsoft Entra ID - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/protect-identities-azure-acative-directory/] & [Windows Hello for Business overview | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/security/identity-protection/hello-for-business/]

Question.Text:
You plan to deploy 25 new Windows 11 devices that will be used by customers to browse the internet in a public location.
You need to recommend a Windows Autopilot mode for the deployment.
What should you recommend?
Question.Explanation: Only self-deploying mode focusses directly on the kiosk mode requirement in the question as you can deploy the Kiosk Browser. [Windows Autopilot self-deploying mode (Public Preview) | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/autopilot/self-deploying]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E3 subscription that includes 500 devices and uses Microsoft Intune. The devices run Windows 10 22H2 and are configured with Windows Recovery Environment.
You need to deploy Windows Autopilot. The solution must minimize the time taken to revert devices to a business-ready state.
What should you do first?

Option.Text: Manually register the devices with Windows Autopilot.

Question.Explanation: The first step is to create a deployment profile that converts all targeted devices to Autopilot devices. You cannot change or reset the machines without being an Autopilot machine. Manually registering with Autopilot requires capturing the hardware hash of each machine. The DisableAutomaticReDeploymentCredentials policy can be configured after the deployment profile and a dynamic device group can be used to target the deployment profile. [Windows Autopilot Reset | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/autopilot/windows-autopilot-reset] & [Configure Autopilot profiles | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/autopilot/profiles]

Question.Text:
Your company is planning to deploy Windows 11 to its global workforce using a zero-touch deployment method. The company has a mix of new and existing devices that need to be configured with the same set of applications and security policies. The goal is to ensure that the deployment process is seamless and requires minimal user interaction.
Which deployment method and settings should you choose to achieve this goal?
Each correct answer presents part of the solution. What two actions should you perform?

Option.Text: Create an Enrollment Status Page (ESP) in Microsoft Intune.
Implement Windows Autopilot for new devices.
Manually install applications on each device.
Use provisioning packages for all devices.

Question.Explanation: Creating an Enrollment Status Page (ESP) in Microsoft Intune (A) is correct because ESP ensures that devices are fully configured with required applications and security policies before users can access them. This helps achieve a zero-touch deployment by verifying the configuration is complete without user intervention. Implementing Windows Autopilot for new devices (C) is also correct because Autopilot automates the deployment and configuration of new devices, enrolling them in Intune and ensuring they are pre-configured with necessary settings, applications, and policies. This reduces manual effort and provides a seamless, zero-touch deployment experience. Deploying Windows 11 using USB drives (B) is incorrect because this method is manual and contradicts the goal of automation. Manually installing applications on each device (D) is incorrect because it increases administrative overhead and does not align with the zero-touch deployment approach. Using provisioning packages for all devices (E) is incorrect because, while useful in certain cases, provisioning packages are not the most scalable or automated solution for a global deployment compared to Windows Autopilot. [Explore Windows Security Center - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/manage-defender-windows-client/2-explore-windows-security-center] & [Explore Windows 365 - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/manage-windows-365/2-explore-windows-365] & [Windows 11 overview for administrators | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/whats-new/windows-11-overview]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.
You have the following devices enrolled in Intune:
Device1: Windows 11
Device2: Android
Device3: iOS
You plan to implement Remediations in Intune to detect and fix common support issues.
On which devices can you use Remediations?
Question.Explanation: Remediations require that devices run Windows 11 Enterprise or Windows 10 Enterprise. Remediations are implemented by creating scripting package(s) and are inapplicable to Android and iOS devices. [Remediations | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/mem/intune/fundamentals/remediations]

Question.Text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes 500 Windows 11 devices that are enrolled in Microsoft Intune.
You create a new configuration profile and deploy it to all Windows 11 devices.
What is the maximum amount of time it may take for a device to apply the new configuration profile?
Question.Explanation: Windows devices which have not been recently enrolled will check-in every 8 hours. Recently enrolled Windows devices checked in more regularly (Every 3 minutes for 30 minutes), however machines that have not enrolled recently will not. [Manage device sync in Intune - Training | Microsoft Learn: https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/monitor-device-profiles/3-manage-device-sync-intune]
